repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: Done with the intention of avoiding reference counting when the constants are accessed from many threads, so my assumption is that it should be on by default in freethreading and user-configurable otherwise. I've skipped code objects because I think that it's pretty infrequent that anyone actually uses them.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
``CYTHON_IMMORTAL_CONSTANTS``
    Makes cached constants (e.g. strings, tuples, ints, floats, slices) immortal,
    in Python versions that support immortality. This is most useful when
    the constants are used in many different threads because it avoids most writes
    to the constants due to reference counting. Disabled by default, but enabled
    in free-threaded builds.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1407,6 +1407,13 @@ most important to least important:
     available in the standard library in Python 3.14 and later.  Cython will then
     fall back to ``zlib`` when compiling in older Python versions.
 
+``CYTHON_IMMORTAL_CONSTANTS``
+    Makes cached constants (e.g. strings, tuples, ints, floats, slices) immortal,
+    in Python versions that support immortality. This is most useful when
+    the constants are used in many different threads because it most writes to
+    the constants due to reference counting and so is only on by default for
+    free-threaded builds.

comment_data.body: I wonder if this would better fit into the `generate_object_constant_decls` method, after generating the constants. The other two usages are also right after filling the arrays.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1605,6 +1605,12 @@ def close_global_decls(self):
         w.exit_cfunc_scope()
 
         w = self.parts['cached_constants']
+        for const_type in ["tuple", "slice"]:
+            if const_type in self.const_array_counters:
+                self.immortalize_constants(
+                    w.name_in_module_state(Naming.pyrex_prefix + const_type),
+                    self.const_array_counters[const_type],
+                    w)

comment_data.body:
I don't think this quite makes sense either - `generate_object_constant_decls` adds it to the module state struct and generates traverse/clear. But it doesn't actually fill the array.

The arrays are filled in a fairly adhoc way as each constant is requested by the code generation.

Practically, if I put it here then gets executed just after the arrays are filled. So I think it's in a good place in the C code, but there might be better places in the Cython code.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1605,6 +1605,12 @@ def close_global_decls(self):
         w.exit_cfunc_scope()
 
         w = self.parts['cached_constants']
+        for const_type in ["tuple", "slice"]:
+            if const_type in self.const_array_counters:
+                self.immortalize_constants(
+                    w.name_in_module_state(Naming.pyrex_prefix + const_type),
+                    self.const_array_counters[const_type],
+                    w)

comment_data.body:
It turns out that CPython has certain rules for immortal strings that are checked in debug builds:
https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/920de7ccdcfa7284b6d23a124771b17c66dd3e4f/Objects/unicodeobject.c#L713-L739

This explodes for (non-identifier) string that are not getting interned. I think we need to exclude strings from the immortal constants for the time being. From a quick look, it doesn't seem easy to get an immortal interned string from the API.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2096,6 +2102,8 @@ def generate_pystring_constants(self, text_strings: list, byte_strings: list):
         w.putln('}')
         w.putln('}')
 
+        self.immortalize_constants("stringtab", len(index), w)

comment_data.body:
We could possibly do something like

```
        self.immortalize_constants(f"stringtab + {first_interned}", len(index) - first_interned, w)
```

to immortalize only the interned strings and the bytes objects (which I don't think have the check)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2096,6 +2102,8 @@ def generate_pystring_constants(self, text_strings: list, byte_strings: list):
         w.putln('}')
         w.putln('}')
 
+        self.immortalize_constants("stringtab", len(index), w)

comment_data.body: I have completely excluded strings for now. IIUC, interned strings are created with `SSTATE_INTERNED_MORTAL`, which also contradicts immortality.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2096,6 +2102,8 @@ def generate_pystring_constants(self, text_strings: list, byte_strings: list):
         w.putln('}')
         w.putln('}')
 
+        self.immortalize_constants("stringtab", len(index), w)

comment_data.body: You're right, though, bytes objects don't have such a check. We could at least include those.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2096,6 +2102,8 @@ def generate_pystring_constants(self, text_strings: list, byte_strings: list):
         w.putln('}')
         w.putln('}')
 
+        self.immortalize_constants("stringtab", len(index), w)

commit.message:
Add an option to immortalize cached constants

Done with the intention of avoiding reference counting when the
constants are accessed from many threads, so my assumption is that
it should be on by default in freethreading and user-configurable
otherwise. I've skipped code objects because I think that it's
pretty infrequent that anyone actually uses them.

Apply suggestions from code review

Co-authored-by: scoder <stefan_ml@behnel.de>
